channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Amid Crisis, Kazakhstan's Leader Embraces Russia
item.description: With his government under siege, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, Kazakhstan’s president, turned to Russia’s Vladimir V. Putin for support. The choice could realign Central Asia’s politics.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev of Kazakhstan last year at the United Nations in New York.

item.title: The New Weddings in India’s South: ‘Expect Some Magic’
item.description: Couples are creating ever more elaborate ceremonies, drawing inspiration from social media trends that blur the nation’s religious and cultural lines.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Suhasini Raj and Anindito Mukherjee
item.media:description: The wedding of Dr. Sheha Pfizer, center, featured a lot of music and dancing, as is often the case in Kerala these days. Her ceremony incorporated influences from around India and beyond, including Sufi, Punjabi, hip-hop and flamenco.

item.title: How Biden and Boris Johnson Reached the Same Place on Virus Policy
item.description: Two different leaders with differing approaches landed on a policy of coexisting with the virus. Analysts say they had little choice.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Enjoying Christmas festivities last month in Manchester, England. Prime Minister Boris Johnson said people did not need to cancel their holiday plans as the virus spread.

item.title: Djokovic Stay at Park Hotel Highlights Australia Asylum Seeker Plight
item.description: The tennis star is quarantining in a Melbourne hotel where asylum seekers have been held for over a year, under a program that has been widely criticized.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Damien Cave
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The police stood in front of the Park Hotel in Melbourne, Australia, on Thursday, as demonstrators protesting the government’s detention policies for asylum seekers were removed.

item.title: In Kazakhstan’s Street Battles, Signs of Elites Fighting Each Other
item.description: The reasons for the bloody crisis in Central Asia remain murky, but experts say popular discontent could mask an old-fashioned power struggle within the ruling faction.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: A military checkpoint in Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Friday.

item.title: Djokovic Tested Positive for Coronavirus in December, His Lawyers Say
item.description: Lawyers for the tennis star, who is appealing Australia’s decision to deny him entry, said the positive test came weeks before he flew to the country.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Srdjan Stevanovic/Euroleague Basketball via Getty Images
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic at a basketball game in Serbia on Dec. 14. He is in quarantine in Australia awaiting a hearing on his appeal of the government’s decision to revoke his visa.

item.title: Billionaire’s Star Rises as She Takes Bold Stance on Racism in Brazil
item.description: Luiza Trajano turned a small family store into a retail giant. Now, a company policy limiting its executive training program to Black applicants is drawing praise, outrage and much soul-searching.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luiza Trajano says her company, Magazine Luiza, is taking overdue steps to diversify its senior ranks and to atone for the brutal legacy of racism in Brazil.

item.title: Jawar Mohammed to Be Released From Prison by Ethiopian President
item.description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed declared the amnesty on Orthodox Christmas and offered to start a dialogue with some opponents after 14 months of war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Oromos calling for the release of prominent opposition figures in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, in October.

item.title: Revival for New Zealand's Moriori Nearly Pushed to Cultural Death
item.description: The Moriori, whose history of peaceful isolation was shattered by violent subjugation, are fighting to establish themselves as a thriving people alongside the Maori.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Cornell Tukiri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of Tommy Solomon on Chatham Island, or Rekohu, in New Zealand. He is known as the last “full-blooded” member of the Moriori people.

item.title: Behind Kazakhstan Unrest, the ‘Strongman’s Dilemma’
item.description: Since the Cold War’s end, most dictatorial governments have collapsed after their ruler’s departure.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: As Kazakhstan’s only ruler since independence, Nursultan Nazarbayev was keenly aware of the difficulties of succession. The unrest in Kazakhstan suggests that the problem may be virtually unresolvable.

item.title: NATO Vows United Response to Russian Aggression Against Ukraine
item.description: Foreign ministers from the alliance, meeting Friday, hope that Moscow will choose diplomacy and de-escalation instead, amid skepticism that Russia is sincere in wanting substantive talks.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Avdiivka, Ukraine, last month. Russia has engaged in a troop buildup near Ukraine and is calling for a Russian zone of influence free of NATO and Western involvement.

item.title: After Killing of Einar, Sweden Struggles With 'Gangster Rap'
item.description: Hip-hop, the country’s most popular music, has quickly become a lightning rod for Sweden’s long-roiling problems with gun violence and gang warfare.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Joe Coscarelli
item.media:description: A memorial at the site where the successful Swedish rapper Einar was shot and killed in October 2021.

item.title: Italian Mafia Fugitive Caught In Spain Thanks to Google Maps
item.description: Investigators had tracked the man to a town in Spain, and an image found online confirmed that the police were on the right track.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: An image taken from Google Street View was used to track down the Sicilian gangster Gioacchino Gammino.

item.title: How the Kazakhstan Protests Started and Why They Matter
item.description: As protests in the oil-rich Central Asian country gain momentum, the events threaten to reverberate across the region.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Riot police during a protest on Wednesday over an increase in energy prices in Almaty, Kazakhstan.

item.title: Chinese Activists Face Subversion Charges for Weekend Gathering
item.description: A weekend get-together in 2019 offered Beijing a chance to deliver a blow to the “rights defense” movement. Now, two key participants face the prospect of years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Allison Zaucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Sifang at home in Los Angeles this month. Mr. Liu was among those who gathered in Xiamen, China, in late 2019 and discussed human rights. He later fled China.

item.title: Chicago's Mayor Rejects Union's Terms for Returning to School
item.description: The standoff between educators and the city’s government shows no signs of abating.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Lori Lightfoot at the police headquarters in Chicago on Tuesday. “Students need to be back” in the classroom, she said on Saturday.

item.title: Heavy Snow Kills 21 at Murree Hill Station in Pakistan
item.description: Stranded in their cars on snow-covered roads, some in the mountainside town of Murree froze to death and others died from carbon monoxide poisoning.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Cars are stuck under fallen trees on a snowy road in Murree, Pakistan, in an image taken from a video on Saturday.

item.title: School disruptions and boosters for adolescents: The week in virus news.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Allison Zaucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students, families and teachers lined up for coronavirus tests at Gardena High School in Los Angeles on Thursday.

item.title: Kazakhstan Arrests Karim Masimov, Ex-Intelligence Chief, on Suspicion of Treason
item.description: The president had dismissed the intelligence chief, Karim Masimov, this week amid violence that may be tied, at least in part, to political infighting.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Karim Masimov, center, in 2017 in Moscow during a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: BlackBerry Phone Service Officially Ends
item.description: BlackBerry was once Canada’s most valuable company and a global force in tech. The final step in its downfall as a phone maker arrived this week.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: A BlackBerry poster at a trade fair in Hanover, Germany, in 2008.

item.title: Why Tesla Soared as Other Automakers Struggled to Make Cars
item.description: The yawning disparity between the performance of the electric car company and established automakers last year reflects the technological change roiling the industry.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Teslas at a charging station in San Diego last year. Tesla sold nearly twice as many vehicles in 2021 as it did in 2020.

item.title: Royal Caribbean Cancels Three Upcoming Cruises
item.description: The company said it had called off planned trips on three ships and pushed back another’s return to cruising to March.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Serenade of the Seas, a Royal Caribbean cruise ship, in Alaska in July.

item.title: Covid Cases Reach Pandemic High at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: The American base has reinstated a mandate for wearing masks indoors in response to an increase in infections.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Members of the American military waiting for their turn to be vaccinated at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba in September. Infections at the base have reached a pandemic high.

item.title: Airlines Strand Passengers Who Partied on Flight Without Masks
item.description: A group of Canadian social media influencers and others flouted Covid-19 rules on a flight to Cancún, Mexico, resulting in airlines leaving many of them without a way home.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: Maskless Canadian passengers partied on a Sunwing Airlines plane. Now they are being investigated for violating the country’s aviation rules and Covid restrictions.

item.title: Alysa Liu Will Miss National Championships After Positive Coronavirus Test
item.description: The teenager had hoped a strong showing would secure her a spot on the U.S. team for the Beijing Winter Olympics next month.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Alysa Liu competing in the short program at the U.S. Figure Skating Championships on Thursday in Nashville.

item.title: F. Sionil Jose, 97, Novelist Who Saw Heroism in Ordinary Filipinos, Dies
item.description: Mr. Jose’s writing, rich in themes drawn from his rural upbringing, amounted to a continuing morality play about poverty and class divisions in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:credit: Luis Liwanag for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: F. Sionil Jose in 2009. He said the heroes of his fiction were “the common people, the foot soldiers who die in the hundreds so that their generals may live.”

item.title: Grichka and Igor Bogdanoff, Twins in an Uneasy Spotlight, Die at 72
item.description: In France they were science-loving TV celebrities (molded by plastic surgery) whose own research was suspect, maybe a hoax. They died within days of each other.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Igor, left, and Grichka Bogdanoff in 2001. They found fame through television stardom, questionable scientific research, extreme plastic surgery and a high-society lifestyle.

item.title: Covid Tests Probed After 100s on 2 Italy-India Flights Test Positive
item.description: Some 300 passengers on two flights who tested positive for the coronavirus upon landing in the northern city of Amritsar are being retested.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar, Gaia Pianigiani and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: Passengers arriving from Italy on Thursday waited to undergo coronavirus testing at Sri Guru Ram Dass Jee International Airport on the outskirts of Amritsar, India.

item.title: C.D.C Director Defends Covid-19 Isolation Guidance
item.description: Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky held the agency’s first independent news briefing since the Trump White House ended them nearly two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in Washington in November. The agency has faced criticism for muddled and opaque pandemic messaging.

item.title: Biden Administration Warns Against Spyware Targeting Dissidents
item.description: The U.S. intelligence community offered steps that would mitigate — but not stop — spyware developed by firms like the NSO Group.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The most insidious spyware can be placed on a phone without having to trick users into clicking a malicious link.

item.title: Chicago families grit their teeth as officials clash with the teachers’ union over virus precautions.
item.dc:creator: Giulia Heyward
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alejandra Martinez with her three sons learning from home.

item.title: Road Salt Works. But It’s Also Bad for the Environment.
item.description: The chemical is effective at keeping roads free of snow and ice, but it also has damaging consequences, according to a growing body of research.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment (Journal)
item.media:description: A salt and plow truck sat abandoned after sliding off the road in icy conditions in Stafford County, Va., this week.

item.title: 12 Covid Vaccine Shots Aren't Enough for 85-Year-Old in India
item.description: The retired postman said he gamed the offline vaccination drive to keep boosting regularly — long before booster shots were a thing anywhere.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Brahmdeo Mandal, 85, said he believed Covid vaccine doses healed many of his ailments.

item.title: A Food Audit
item.description: The annual instinct to improve your eating isn’t crazy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Laura Moss for The New York Times
item.media:description: The produce aisle at a grocery store in New Jersey.

item.title: Hong Kong Quarantines Dozens of Officials After a Birthday Party
item.description: Those being sent to shipping-container-like dormitories include the city’s police chief and at least 20 lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang, Choe Sang-Hun, Gaia Pianigiani, Isabel Kershner, Christopher F. Schuetze and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Hong Kong’s Legislative Council this week. At least 20 lawmakers were among those sent to quarantine after attending a birthday party on Monday, an embarrassment to the unpopular government.

item.title: Once revered, Djokovic and other star athletes who refuse the vaccine are now scorned.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic at the final match of the Australian Open last year.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Is “forever boosting” tenable?
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Waiting after booster shots at a vaccination center in Brussels this week.

item.title: North Korea Says It Will Skip Beijing Olympics Because of the Pandemic
item.description: The country also blamed “hostile forces” for its decision not to send a delegation to China, its closest ally.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: North Korean cheerleaders waving the country’s flag at a figure-skating event during the 2018 Winter Olympic Games in February 2018 in Pyeongchang, South Korea.

item.title: How Is the South Coast Healing, After the Fires and With Covid?
item.description: A little bit of empathetic momentum can go a long way toward helping people and places heal.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Land clearing in Mogo, Australia, has become common since the fires, as residents fear the bush more now than ever before.

item.title: In Kazakhstan, Putin Again Seizes on Unrest to Try to Expand Influence
item.description: But a series of revolts against a pro-Russian strongman could also plant the seeds of rebellion at home, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: A military checkpoint in Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Friday.

item.title: Scientists Endorse Covid Boosters, But to a Point
item.description: Everyone should get a booster shot. In the long run, though, doses every few months aren’t a viable public health strategy, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: At a nursing home in Petah Tikva, Israel, a man received a fourth Covid vaccine dose.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden warns of threats to democracy
item.description: U.S. lawmakers commemorate last year’s attack on the Capitol.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: President Biden delivered remarks on Thursday in Statuary Hall of the U.S. Capitol.

item.title: Pakistan Paves Way for Ayesha Malik to Be First Woman Supreme Court Justice
item.description: Justice Ayesha A. Malik’s nomination, intensely opposed by some lawyers that have threatened to strike, was hailed by others as an important victory in improving representation for women.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Pakistan’s Supreme Court building in Islamabad last year. A parliamentary committee is expected to approve the court’s first woman justice.

item.title: Canadian Law Banning ‘Conversion Therapy’ Set to Go Into Effect
item.description: The law, which takes effect on Friday, puts Canada in the company of more than a dozen countries that have banned the widely discredited practice.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada, right, shook hands with Erin O’Toole, the Conservative leader, after the unanimous adoption of legislation banning so-called conversion therapy last month.

item.title: In ‘African Origin’ Show at Met, New Points of Light Across Cultures
item.description: Holdings from Ancient Egypt and sub-Saharan Africa come together in a masterpiece show. Now the Met should make clear how the wondrous works got here.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.media:credit: Seth Caplan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Partnerships: Spanning eras and cultures, a pairing of artworks from “The African Origin of Civilization” includes “The King’s Acquaintances Memi and Sabu” from Egypt, ca. 2575–2465 B.C. and “Seated Couple” from Mali, 18th or early 19th century.

item.title: Ethics Adviser Rebukes Boris Johnson Over Downing Street Decorations
item.description: The adviser said it was “plainly unsatisfactory” that he was not told that Mr. Johnson had petitioned a prominent donor to arrange financing for the makeover of his apartment.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson last month in London.

item.title: Pope Scolds Couples Who Choose Pets Over Kids
item.description: Expressing concern about global birthrates, Francis said such couples were acting in a selfish way that diminished humanity.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: Novak Djokovic Collides With Australia’s Covid Fight
item.description: Barring the tennis star from entering the country offers a chance to change the subject as an election looms and coronavirus cases are at record highs.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Ben Solomon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic at the U.S. Open in last year. He has been dismissive toward the pandemic, and has emerged as professional tennis’s most prominent vaccine skeptic.

item.title: Republicans for Democracy
item.description: American democracy may depend on a conservative-liberal alliance.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liz Cheney at a hearing last month.

item.title: Xi'an Is China's Biggest Covid Challenge Since Wuhan
item.description: Xi’an, a city of 13 million people, has been on lockdown since Dec. 22, the longest in the country since the early days of the outbreak in Wuhan.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Residential buildings at night in Xi’an, China, where a lockdown that began Dec. 22 has required all residents to stay at home to help curb the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: Cruise Ships Are Still Sailing as Cases Rise and Criticism Mounts
item.description: One day after the C.D.C. advised against all travel on cruise ships, thousands of cruisers partied like it was 2019. But worries about onboard policies — and frustration over quarantines — are rising.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: The German cruise ship AIDAnova, docked in Lisbon, celebrated New Year’s Eve with fireworks.

item.title: Why Novak Djokovic Was Blocked From Entering Australia
item.description: The men’s No. 1 tennis player had received an exemption to the country’s vaccine requirements. Then the federal government stepped in.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Alana Holmberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic at the Australian Open last year.

item.title: North Korea Defector Crosses DMZ Border Twice
item.description: Officials say a North Korean who crossed the DMZ in 2020 crossed it again to go back. His life in the South seems to have been one of poverty and isolation.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers at the Demilitarized Zone, the heavily fortified buffer zone along the border with North Korea.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Emmanuel Macron lashes out at the unvaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France made it clear he wanted to make the lives of the unvaccinated harder.

item.title: Emerging Data Raise Questions About Antigen Tests and Nasal Swabs
item.description: A new study adds to evidence that common rapid tests may fail to detect some Omicron cases in the first days of infection.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rapid antigen Covid test kits at Miami International Airport on Tuesday.

item.title: Rio Cancels Carnival Street Parties but Keeps Parade
item.description: As the Omicron variant sweeps the globe, the parties in Rio de Janeiro, which ordinarily draw millions of revelers, have been called off for a second year.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: A performance during the last night of Rio de Janeiro’s Carnival parade in 2020.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Variant Déjà Vu in India
item.description: Doctor shortages, surging cases and mixed messaging.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Arranging medical beds inside a temporary Covid-19 care facility in a trade center in Chennai, India, on Wednesday.

item.title: Using Harsh Language, Macron Issues a Challenge to the Unvaccinated
item.description: The French president was seeking to tap into a rich political vein: anger among the majority of vaccinated people at a minority who refuse to get vaccinated and disproportionately occupy hospital beds.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, pictured in December, said he wanted to “piss off” millions of his citizens who refuse to get vaccinated.
